Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Computing and Geoscience in the Coastal Carolina Region
Award.AbstractNarration:
Problems in Geoscience relevant to the coastal regions and climate change span a broad spectrum of disciplines: oceanography, atmospheric science, geology, computer science, data science, chemistry, engineering, and biology. Solutions to these problems can have strong socioeconomic impacts. Advances in computing and big data analytics are essential in obtaining these solutions, allowing us to make appropriate assessment of resources in light of future issues related to climate change. These solutions likewise require broad thinking that can only be afforded by promoting diversity. However, Geoscience has historically produced the lowest number of minority doctorates in STEM and has been one of the least diverse disciplines. Similarly, gender inequality has continued to plague Computer Science.

The REU site provides opportunities for undergraduates to conduct research projects that integrate computing and geoscience to advance on-going research activities related to coastal zones, climate variability, and big data analysis. For example, research activities by REU students will help seek ways to improve climate forecasting, better understand physical processes in the coastal zones, increase national preparedness for climate change, understand the nexus between food, energy and water and mitigate the impacts of natural disasters. To promote interest and increase diversity in Geoscience and Computer Science, underrepresented students will be recruited from South Carolina, nearby states, and the Southeastern U.S. region, especially those attending all-women and historically black colleges and universities with limited research opportunities. The REU site's goals are (1) to increase the percentage of women and other underrepresented students in graduate programs and careers in Computer Science and Geoscience, (2) to provide meaningful research experiences in computing intensive research topics of societal relevance, and (3) to provide a supportive environment for students to improve their research, critical-thinking, problem-solving and communication skills.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This REU site addressed problems related to coastal regions and climate change while training and engaging undergraduates in scientific research. Encompassing geoscience, computing sciences, data science and related core scientific disciplines, research activities by REU students over the last three years helped to improve weather forecasting, understand physical processes in the coastal zones,  address social computing techniques from a disaster resilience standpoint, increase preparedness for climate change, characterize flood vulnerability of residential communities using GIS, diagnose biogeochemical processes at ocean facing beaches, evaluate data mining and statistical models for oceanography related data, assess forecast models using satellite data, develop digital visualization and reconstruction of landscape and south Santee River flow (historical sites in coastal south Carolina regions), model the impact of coastal sea level on river flooding, and analyze ensemble numerical weather prediction data for determining atmospheric refractivity. Research outcomes were disseminated through annual technical reports, the REU web site, student presentations at the REU site’s colloquium, and poster presentations in the American Geophysical Union (AGU) and American Meteorological Society (AMS) meetings.

With respect to broader impacts, this REU site aimed to (a) increase diversity in graduate programs and careers related to Computer Science and Geoscience, (b) improve student skills in research, critical-thinking, problem-solving, and communication, and (c) provide meaningful research experiences in computing intensive research topics related to geoscience.

With respect to aim (a), the site actively reached out to targeted institutions (HBCUs, women-only liberal arts institutions, etc.) by making annual recruitment presentations, resulting in at least 30% of our application pool coming from these targeted institutions. Nearly 50% of our REU student participants were from these targeted institutions. As part of the REU student orientation, we had a professional from the Division of Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion talk to the REU students, faculty advisors, and graduate student mentors about the importance of diversity and inclusion. The orientation also included cohort-building activities. These efforts were appreciated by the REU student participants in their exit surveys.

With respect to aim (b), the site conducted technical workshops in the week 1 of the program and professional development sessions almost every week from week 2 to week 9. The professional development and technical workshops helped the REU students to complete drafts of  their technical paper, poster presentation, and the oral presentation.

With respect to aim (c), the site fostered a collaborative environment that encouraged REU student interactions with the faculty advisors and graduate student mentors so that the REU students could successfully implement the research skills that they learned. The provided professional development sessions included how to perform literature review, conduct research ethically, and present their research results. Students were also encouraged to use our NSF-funded cyberinfrastructure in addition to institutional computing support to execute their research projects.
